Here is the ellipsoid x^2/4 ^ y^2/6 +z^2/3=1, labeled with its equation. There is a second .stl file showing the surface without the equation.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16). For more information see http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/16/quadratic-surfaces-ellipsoid/.

This object was made on a MakerBot2X. We used the following settings:
2 shells
0.20mm layer height
10% infill (hexagonal pattern)
Color matched supports
Raft on

We recommend building with a raft, just in case the object falls over.
We also rotated this object before printing, so that the equations printed on the top, not the side.

author: JY_Printr

description.text:
Short: Its a scalable customizable ship build set. You can make it as short or long as you want. I will be making more parts to turn it in to other boats as well as rc functions in the future. Feel free to make your own customizations.

Long:This ship is my first entry for the make it float challenge. I found the challenge instructions very broad, having no size limit I assumed the object would have to fit on a maker bot instead of a huge 12x12 printer. With that in mind I made this container ship out of interchangeable components that could fit on a standard printer and be assembled after. I made it in multiple parts because the challenge was aimed at seeing how much weight(currency) an entry can hold. The law of buoyancy states that the upward force from the water is directly proportional to the amount of water displaced by the object. So in reality shape has nothing to do with flotation other then stability. Its the size of the object that determines the amount of weight it can hold. So to hold more weight you must displace more water. No matter how fancy the design is, it comes down to the bigger the better. So in reality a giant box would work the best but I found that a design like that fails to make any kind of aesthetic appeal which I believe brings life and inspiration from science (nature does a real good job of it.)

Features:
○Sturdy construction; Keep playing with it like a play set after you print it.
○Customization; Mix and match and print however many you want to build any size of boat.
○Segmented; Many smaller parts allow for a larger boat from even the smallest printers.

Print settings; To print at the intended size the print must be scaled up by a factor of 10 but can be set to any size that you like but cny smaller then 5 the printable clips wont work. You can use staples or super glue or just print the parts pre-assembled. I recommend 2-3 perimeters and 3 or more top and bottom layers. 18% infill, more is needed for smaller prints. 0.2 mm layer height. All parts can be printed facing up except the helm and the clips which can be printed face down.

Assembly; Clips are used to hold the parts together. Place as many parts together as you like.

You know all the claws on claw machines that are rigged to not work? I decided to make a robot with something similar on the front that's actually reliable. All these parts were designed by me from scratch. I am rather proud of how it is coming together. I will post images of what I have so far and the finished product later.

I uploaded the Inventor IPT files to keep this thing as open source as possible!

I know that the Cage File contains 3 in one. This way you only need import one of the Cage.stl files to have a full cage. These are also designed to be expandable. For instance; you can print 2 Cage's and have 6 gears. Granted, you will have to modify the worm Cog.ipt to match the new setup. I will try to make the worm gear compatible with customizer after I am happy with the base design.

The Idea is to mount this ( http://amzn.to/1fbViKV )motor to the worm gear and have the motor mount center it between the 3 gears.

Worm Gear (exT) is the latest version of the worm gear and it seems like it would work the best. I am yet to actually test it because I need to modify the worm gear to fit the gear motors shaft

Please Refer to the Assembly file to see how to put it together!

Doesn't Matter

3x Cog.stl

title: Ultimaker Belt and Axis Tension Nut Replacement

description.text:
This part replaces the laser cut part "C" used in the X and Y axis sliders on a current Ultimaker.  
The stock part has the problem of allowing the nut to spin freely, preventing proper belt tension and inevitably vibrating loose. This solid nut solves that problem.

Use with the excess 16mm screws from the assembly of your Ultimaker. It is important that you thread the screw through this part as soon as the print finishes, so that you form the threads while the plastic is still soft.  
100% infill, 50mm/s speed, 0.2 layer height with duplicate outlines enabled.

remixed_from.title: FlexMesh 2.1 Snap Together Flexible Chainmail Mesh

description.text: I love this chainmail design so much and thought it would make a great gift for the crafty types in my life, so I combined a few things and came up with this tight little package. My variation uses only tris and subs which are scaled down to 60% for higher resolution designs. I found that at 60%, these are harder to connect, requiring a small pair of pliers, but overall stayed together better.
I print serially; I switch filament color at 2mm in height so the pieces are double sided, which gives broad variation with only 2 pieces. I use ca glue to mount the pliers sleeve to the lid.

description.text:
this small ruler can be used as scale reference while taking pictures of your archaeological find - erm - your latest thingiverse design ;-)

based on this 2d-print photographic reference scale by Jim Elder

features:

  • overall size is ~10x~2cm
  • several centimeter squares and millimeter ruler for reference
  • a 2cm diameter ring for perspective correction
  • a gray area for color correction
  • mounting holes (for your keyring, backpack, ...)

i printed this with a 0.4mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer-height and 0.3mm extrusion width (which is rather experimental) to get the fine detail for the millimeter tick-marks

prints wonderfully as pseudo dual-color print: print the bottom layers in black, pause, hotswap to white and continue with the top layers (markings/squares/...) :-)

alternatively print the whole thing in white and paint it black/gray

a piece of duct-tape also works quite well as gray color reference area (might be a bit glossy though)
This is just a remix of DanLuc's lens cap holder rotated so the writing is face up. This is useful for people like me who use Slic3r. I hope this speeds things up

description.text:

Press fit in a vise with 2 rod ends stacked, this version still causes some plastic deformation when pressing without heat (haven't actually tried with heat yet). Maybe will reduce thickness to make pressing easier. I have purchased other bead sizes and will try those as well soon.

I want to try using this for RC cars and maybe a kossel, haven't tried either yet.

I have an Intex Easy Set pool and I want to heat it.
How? Using my bbq: I made a heat-exchanger from a copper pipe to put on the bbq and I will run the water from the pump through this heat-exchanger and back in the pool.
This splitter is needed after the pump to divert a part of the water through your garden hose to the bbq.

This is a piece which will fit after the pump: on exit will connect the normal hose, the other can be used to connect a 16mm (exterior) garden hose.

To optimize the flow, the garden hose is inserted into the printed piece, to not loose any diameters on that side.
Also the intersection is optimized for the water flow.

ATTENTION: this is a work in progress, this has not been tested yet.
And even when it will be tested and completed: running water over the bbq is DANGEROUS. Keep your kids away from the bbq and make sure the pump keeps running when doing this, else you get steam in this pipe and this can have nasty consequences for your pool and everyone around it.
If you decide to do this as described, this is completely at your own risk!

UPDATE: After testing this piece and making some adjustments for printing margins, this piece does not seem to work.
The small hose has too much resistance (in my case) so all the water is going through the big hose and none through the garden hose. My heat exchanger does have a few bad corners in it and a leak: I will try to fix those and test again.

After fixing the stock cloth case twice, and having the velcro wear out completely, I decided I needed to print a new case. My first try was a customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335122 which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:335786 . Unfortunately I did not like how flimsy the case felt, and it never quite fit right. Also, I tend to wack my knife on everything when it is on my belt, so I needed to have a VERY robust clip, but printing it all in one piece meant having to choose between a robust clip or a robust case. Eventually I decided to start from scratch, and decided to make the clip and the case two parts to ensure both could be printed at maximum strength.

Presenting the Gerber Suspension Quick Click Case

Now after several months of testing, use, dropping, wacking and other general abuse, and a reinforcing of the clip, I can now say that this design is worthy of sharing, and works great!

Features:

  • Simple slide in mechanism provides one handed retrieval and return
  • Satisfying "Click" action when the tool is fully inserted
  • Reinforced belt clip survives even my worst abuse (drops, wacks, you name it I have done it)
  • Simple design requires no support to print

Step 1: Print case (oriented with opening up) and clip (on its side) parts at 100% infill with maximum number of perimeters you can (I did 3). I recommend ABS or HIPS for impact strength, and for easy bonding via solvent welding.

Step 2: Sand the back side of the case and the flat side of the clip until they are smooth. This will ensure maximum surface contact for gluing/welding.

Step 3: Glue or solvent weld the flat side of the clip to the back of the case with the rounded end flush with the opening of the case. (I tried putting it a bit lower the first time, but it always felt top heavy on my belt, and fell off easier, but exact positioning is however you prefer).

Step 4: CLICK!

author: rgreenosborne

description.text:
I wanted to have a way to put my UE Boom on my bicycle where I could hear it (instead of a backpack). This is what I came up with.

Modify as you see fit. I make no promises on stability or durability, but it works for me. Use at your own risk, and try to take it easy when you have it mounted. I printed it with ABS, and it "seems" fairly strong, but I haven't tested it thoroughly (trails, major bumps, etc.).

Autodesk 123d Model: http://www.123dapp.com/123D_Design/UE-Boom-Bicycle-Mount/4192125

Update:

  1. I've ridden the bike with the mount and speaker for a good few rides. It's taken bumps and turns and seen no problems.

  2. I took a spill on my bike this morning due to a crowded sidewalk and a drop-off. The speaker fell out of the mount, because I only had it in there with earplugs, but the mount didn't take any damage. I recommend finding a way to secure the speaker into the housing if you're going to be doing anything rough.

I printed this on high quality. I used the "Everywhere" support setting, due to the many overhanging parts. The support was not too difficult to remove, but the pieces under the bracket did require a pair of pliers and a bit of hacksaw work.

Use sandpaper to smooth out the edges so you do not have any burrs that will catch on your speaker housing.

I suggest you use a rubber shim in the bracket portion so it does not scratch your bicycle. Additionally, use two foam earplugs, compressed longitudinally, underneath the font of the speaker. This provides some shock dampening for your speaker and keeps it securely in place.

If you wish to secure the speaker in using a rubber band or similar device, more power to you.

You'll need to pop out the bracket holes, as the support fills them in a bit. It's a simple task, but you'll have to clean up the hex hole a bit. I recommend a dental pick.

If your bicycle tube is thick, you might have to use a zip tie through the holes to secure it. Otherwise, if the tube fits, and your rubber shim is well-fitted, you can use an M5 bolt and nut. The hex hole is the size of an M5, and you can use a wingnut to secure it, but you will have to drill out the hole a little bit to make the bolt fit easily.

comments.text: great idea! but it snapped when i went of a curb so i had to make some improvements
comments.author: louria123

comments.text: Sorry about that! I ended up moving it to my seat post so it has a spot to rest on the bar. It's gotta have some padding to be perfect due to the nature of a rough ride on bicycles. You make a good point, too, that the small cross-piece holding the two sides together to support the structure... could be widened at both sides to reinforce it. It could look like an hourglass to allow enough sound to escape.

author: kurt19

description.text:
Replacement spindle and turntable for filament spools with 16mm cores for the OVerlord series 3D printer.
The spindle is somewhat parametric, and can be easily modified for almost any core size over 10mm in diameter. (The hole in the turntable is 10mm diameter) It's NOT designed for full-size spools, though. (I made if because of a 300gram spool)

1. Print the Platter.
  2. Measure the core of the spool.
  3. If the hole is 16mm, go ahead and also print the Spindle.
  4. If not, open the spindle.scad file in OpenScad(or beg me), edit to fit core diameter and export a new .stl whach can be printed.
  5. Glue pieces together.
  6. Enjoy...

Replacement hook for Hoover vacuum.
First try not perfect, but it works very well!

Printed with Zortrax M200
Z-ULTRAT, Layer 0.14mm, Infill FULL, support 20°

remixed_from.author: orangefurball
remixed_from.title: E3D v6 Bowden Printrbot Simple (Rear Y Homing)

description.text:
This custom Bowden conversion can be printed on the Printrbot Simple 1405 (though mine has been upgraded already).

By replacing the extruder with a 3D printed hot end mount, it is possible to increase the performance of a budget printer like the Simple. The extruder motor seat just gives a nice place for the motor to lie upright without moving around (I forgot to account for my heatsink, so mine doesn't sit all the way but it works otherwise). There are M3 screw holes on the seat in case I decide to fix it onto something in the future.

The "Small Extruder Mount" is meant to work with the existing Printrbot Alu Extruder.

The hot end mount is basically remixed from Orangefurball's part. The "L" shaped end of it that hits the Y endstop is raised slightly in order to fit on the wooden 1405 frame, in case you're not using the Y-axis no sag mod from Jon Lawrence.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A3h2oEbLh0U

My hot end mount was printed in ABS with about 30% fill and 3 perimeters. I had it done in ABS because I was still using the Ubis at the time and heat creep was an issue. Since upgrading to an E3D Lite6 this is no longer a concern. If you print with PLA and are using the Ubis or another hot end that doesn't stay very cool, I'd suggest bumping up the infill to >=40%.

For the Small Extruder Mount and Motor Seat, I printed mine at 25% infill and 3 perimeters--not as much need for a solid part here, so print how you like.

You will need to source extra M3 screws for the Small Extruder Mount piece. I believe I used 6mm M3 screws. For the hot end mount, I kept the same hardware, although I did add an M3 nut that for the 20mm M3 screw to grab onto when tightening the hot end into place.

Add 2mm ID/4mm OD PTFE tubing to your desired length.

You will also need some 4mm push to connect tube fittings. One end is threaded, so you can screw them into the plastic parts by hand. I ordered mine from here.

comments.text: I'm not familiar with the 1405. Is that a DIY specific version? I am trying to get this to work with my simple metal and it doesn't seem that the holes that mount the extruder to the simple metal are the correct size/location.
comments.author: Chozandrias

comments.text: This was made for wooden DIY model that released in 2014. That being said, I can't guarantee that a newer Simple Metal would follow the same mounting geometry. Perhaps there are other Bowden designs made for the SM, or if you knew what the hole dimensions were I could make a separate version.
comments.author: Chozandrias

comments.text: Ok, that is what I was thinking. My printer is both inoperable and slightly unique. I ordered a print of your parts and they didn't quite fit in all aspects. I'll have to just redesign the setup based on what I can figure out.
comments.author: roijeric

comments.text: why is the extruder mount on its side?
comments.author: Shanjaq

comments.text: Ah, just what I was looking for! Quick question - are you using Jon's short front piece? I saw some mentions in the comments on his 300mm No Sag mod that even the short piece doesn't fit the E3D V6. However, I've seen many different Bowden setups that are using V6's with no issues. Just want to make sure I'll be all set when my new hotend gets here! (Silly Ubis toasted itself...)
comments.author: LumberjackEngineering

comments.text: Yep! I haven't had any issues. The "standard" diameter you'll find on most hot ends is 16 mm with some kind of mounting groove. The hot end mount here was actually made with the Ubis in mind, but I use it with my E3D anyway. Holds pretty much from friction.
comments.author: LumberjackEngineering

Dieses Spielbrett bremst Ihre Katze dabei, alle Köstlichkeiten auf einmal zu sich zu nehmen. Wenn man die Leckerlis in die Mitte des Spielbrettes gibt, kann sich die Katze damit amüsieren, sie aus dem Labyrinth heraus zu bugsieren.

Falls Ihre Katze keine Erfahrung mit Spielzeugen dieser Art hat, empfiehlt es sich, das Brett in Y-Richtung herunterzuskalieren. Dadurch wird der Schwierigkeitsgrad reduziert.

This game board prevents your cat from eating all her treats at once. If you put her delights in the middle of the board you give your cat the opportunity of amusing herself by getting them out of the labyrinth.

In case your cat has no experience with this kind of toys, I recommend to scale it down in Y-direction to reduce the level of difficulty.

title: RBA Winery Addition
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A small winery addition we have been working on, it took a number of hours of trial and error and a few failed prints to get to the stage where a 1:100 model could successfully be printed.  
The original file was created in Archicad and printed on our Replicator 2. Originally tried to print using default 'high' settings on Makerware, the print was very slow, fragile and often would not complete at all. This example was printed with default 'medium' settings (10% infill, 2 shells, Makerbot slicer, 0.27mm layer height) and was much more succesful. Some support was designed into the model for window openings and was easy to cut out.   
If any one has been attempting similar prints and has found certain things that work or don't work, feedback would be appreciated.   
Regards,  
RBA

comments.text: for my are very difficult print architecture but im an architect, could you give me some recommendations
comments.author: arqmartintrejo

comments.text: We have found that with our printer that 0.22mm layer height, 10% infill and 3 shells seems to work fairly well. You also need to model little supports under large openings, and try not to model anything that will scale to smaller than 1mm.
comments.author: arqmartintrejo

This is the iconic Luna spaceship from the 1950 sci-fi classic Destination Moon, with backgrounds by Chesley Bonestell, who was the technical advisor for the film's astronomical art.

Based on a model in the SketchUp 3D Warehouse by MorBius (https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=24db45a97b5b8a616a12484fa9d9be10), the one-piece version was cleaned up and repaired in Netfabb, then printed in PLA with supports and raft enabled.

2015-10-21 Update: I have posted a file called "Luna-Thicker Wings.stl", which prints better than the original "Destination Moon" file.

Luna Top and Luna Bottom are based on this version, if you want to print a larger model.
Those with a well-tuned printer should be able to print Luna Bottom/Top without support. (Update: but the V2 versions posted in Dec. 2016 print better still!)

A display stand for Luna is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:654300

2016-12-31 Update: Luna-simplified.stl and a couple of screw-together models designed for printing at larger sizes are now the recommended version for printing. Luna-simplified should print well at any size. No support is needed for these new models, which are recommended over all previous versions. Thanks to muzz64 for the screw-together parts.

title: Mariner 4 Flyby 50th Anniversary Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This simple snap and glue model is In honor of the 50th anniversary of NASA's Mariner 4 flyby of Mars. Plenty of detail, right down to the magnetometer on the low-gain antennae mast!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25 mm

Infill:

10%

1) Print the parts, the full sheet is designed for the Replicator2. Individual parts are all clipped to the XY Plane and roughly centered, there are also files for the panels and body as separate prints. Everything is designed for support free printing in PLA with a downward fan, trust me ;-).

2) Use the full model and photos as reference for assembly. A few drops of glue appropriate for your plastic of choice will attach the camera pod to the bottom of the spacecraft.

3) Make plenty of engine swooshing sounds as you fly your antique spacecraft model around the house, office, or any public space of your choosing.

4) Live Long and Prosper.

remixed_from.title: Proximity sensor mount for i3 Rework E3D Extruder v3

title: Proximity Senson Holder for Prusa i3 Rework 1.0 Extruder Wade

description.text:
This proximity sensor holder is for the "Inductive Proximity Sensor Detection Switch NPN 4mm DC6-36V LJ12A3-4-Z/BX".

I bought this sensor in eBay to ouyou2010
http://www.ebay.co.uk/usr/ouyou2010?_trksid=p2047675.l2559

It can be found here:
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/131402459032?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The extruder body that I have is this one:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616

I created this in FreeCAD from scratch but based on the work of http://www.thingiverse.com/fotogravinci

Main goals for this design are:

  • Right for the Wade Extruder of the Prusa i3 rework.
  • 3D printable without supports.
  • Small profile and rounded edges for low resistance to air flow from hot end fan.
  • Keeps its distance from the hot end to avoid overheating.

If you are after the sources please go to github:
https://github.com/rafadesu/proximitysensorholder

Enjoy it!

I've printed it using:

  • 4 perimeters.
  • 0.35 layers.
  • 0.4 mm extruder.
  • 204 degrees.
  • 4 layer top/bottom at 100% infill.
  • Rest at 30% linear infill.

Ever dreamed of hanging your hammock in your house?

So have I! That's why I designed this weird looking thing^^ I made it round with no sharp corners just in case someone were to bang there head into in. Also, it was made with three places for screws to evenly distribute the weight to the studs in your house. You will have to drill your own holes but that way you can mount it however you want. You will want to do a very heavy infill so it can handle your weight and the screws.

To attach a rope to it you will have to have a loop on the end. All you got to do is stick it through the hole in between the to balls and then put it around the thing sticking up and then your good to go.

remixed_from.title: [1.5.1] 3uP - Metal H-Bot Upgrade for QUBD Two-Up

title: 3UP Printer XY Bearing parts for 608 BB

description.text: Uses 608RS bearings rather than the 3/8" center hole bearings from the one/two up. Motivation is that I keep needing my one up printer to make parts but want to put my oversized 3UP together and don't want to buy more parts. Bought 16 608RS bearings (they are cheap) and might as well use them though out the design.

comments.text: It wouldn't be hard at all to put in a different bearing.  Just get the source files from the 3UP and remix them.  They import fine into Fusion 360.  I didn't have to change anything other than the diameter of the support because the outer bearing diameter didn't change to use the 608's.  If you use a different diameter then the bearing placement will have to move.

title: Custom light atmosphere cube (finished look soon online... sry)

description.text:
Brighten up your moods with this little light cube whose faces are customizable! =)

I modeled a small cube to integrate components of a luminaire downgraded but if you want the recesses "standarts" I can still edit...

It's powered by 3 AA batteries of 1.5 volts and activated by a pushbutton.

I don't have a sufficiently high print resolution with my Printrbot... But let me know if all the pieces fit together well or whether to adjust plz!

• Print base (x1) + side (x4) + top (x1) + frame (x1) + tip (x4) + led holder full (x1) OR for those printing problems : led holder top (x1) + led holder bot (x1).
  • Assemble and wire the electronic components and led holder to the base according to drawing.
  • Assemble (and optionally glue only for these parts) sides and tips to the base.
  • Choose your pictures and cut them to size : 70x75 mm for sides and 70x70 mm for top (max thickness : 2 mm).
  • Drag the pictures into the appropriate slots, block one above with the frame and close the top.
  • Turn it on and enjoy! (y)

This is one of a series of educational displays I made for the Arcade Library in Sacramento to help teach people about 3D printing.

It can be difficult to explain important 3D printing concepts like printing with supports, the effect of the number of shells, resolution, infill percentage and using a raft.

Sometimes all you need is a good visual aid to make things click.

This is a shell display that shows the effect of different "number of shells" settings. A one inch cube is printed ten times with various settings. Cubes with 1-5 shells are on one row and then 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 shells are on the next row. It is easy to see how the number of shells effects the stability of a print and the translucency.

There is enough space between the cubes to squeeze them to feel how flexible or ridged they are.
It's a great way to quickly find out how many shells you should use for your project.

See the instructions for details on how to make this display for your classroom or wherever else it is useful.

You will need to print the file "25mm cube.stl" ten times.
Print times get longer as you print the cube with more shells, the longest print was 40-50 minutes

Print each cube with 0% infill and 0.3mm layer height.
Print the first cube with 1 shell. Before the print finishes, cancel the print. Do this before the printer seals the top of the cube and you can't see inside of it.

EDIT: It has been brought to my attention that there is a setting called "top layer height" in the advanced settings of MakerWare and Cura. Setting this to 0 will print the block without the top automatically, so you won't need to cancel the print at the end to leave it open so you can see the inside.

When I printed these cubes I put the first cube next to the cube that I was printing near the end of the print, and then canceled the print when it was approximately the same height.

Print the 2nd thru 5th cubes each with 2, 3, 4, 5 shells, 0% infill and 0.3mm layer height.

Do the same with 5 more cubes with the shell settings: 10, 15, 20, 25 and 30 shells.

The next step is printing "Display Row 1-5.stl" and "Display Row 10-30.stl"

I used the settings 5% infill and 2 shells and 0.3mm layer height.

Pick two colors, one for the letters one for the background. Load the filament of your choice for the background and start the print, when the printer starts to print the first layer of the letters and is done with the rest of the model go to "change filament" in the menu of your 3D printer. Then proceed to unload filament you were printing with and load the filament you have chosen for the letters. Then continue the print. Do these steps for both files. I would not recommend printing both files at once in case you make a mistake and have to start over.

Do the same steps for "Number of Shells Display Label.stl" that goes on the front of the display.

Last print the "display steps.stl" file in the color filament of your choosing.
The settings I used were 0.3mm layer height, 2 shells and 5% infill.

Now glue everything together. I glued the cubes down to the display so they do not get lost.

The glue I used is "Model & Hobby Cement" from the dollar store. It's strong but not so strong that you cannot get it apart if you make a mistake.

Enjoy! Teach and spread the knowledge of 3D printing!

description.text:
Edit: Now in TWO sizes, check the files 27mm and 23mm diameter motors. (ie. 27mm = 2204/2206 sizes, 23mm = 1804/1806 sizes)

Motor wrench I made for my quadcopter to easy changing propellers without having to grip really hard. You can scale it to your specific motor size. I scaled one down for smaller 23mm diameter sized motors. The original is for a 27mm diameter motor.

You WILL need supports or else the joint will collapse. Need the design tweaked for your specific motor? Let me know the dimensions.

Once printed, drive a wire/rod with enough diameter through to snuggly fit the hole. Then bend the ends into the wrench itself using pliers. No need to use heavy gauge wires or screws, there is no load on the joint, as it is merely to keep the wrench in one piece.

description.text:
This is one of a series of educational displays I made for the Arcade Library in Sacramento to help teach people about 3D printing.

It can be difficult to explain important 3D printing concepts like infill percentage, shells, resolution, and the need for supports.

Sometimes all you need is a visual aid to make things click.

This is a infill display that shows the effect of different infill percent settings. A one inch cube is printed fifteen times with various settings. Cubes with 0-20 percent infill are on the first row and then 25-50% infill are on the next row followed by 60-100% on the top row. It is easy to see how the infill percentage effects a print.

See the instructions for details on how to make this display for your classroom, or anywhere else it will be useful.

I've also included the SketchUp files if you would like to make changes.

See the shell display in this photo here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:927684

Start by printing out the "25mm cube.stl" with the following settings: 0.3mm layer height, 2 shells and 0% infill. Cancel the print before the printer finishes printing the top of the cube so you can see the infill inside of the cube.

Repeat the cube print 14 more times changing the infill percent to 5% 10% 15% 20% 25% 30% 35% 40% 50% 60% 70% 80% 90% 100%

Use the first cube you printed to judge when to stop the next prints so the cubes are all the same height.

Tip: you can print the middle and last row of cubes shorter (cancel them sooner so they are not as tall) because they take much longer to print with such a high infill percentage.

The next step is printing "20.stl" and "50.stl" and "100.stl"

I used the settings 5% infill and 2 shells and 0.3mm layer height.

Pick two colors, one for the letters and one for the background of the letters. Load the filament of your choice for the background of the letters and start the print. When the printer has finished the last layer of the rectangular part of the label and starts the the first layer of the letters go to "change filament" in the menu of your 3D printer. Then proceed to unload the filament you were printing with, and load the filament you have chosen for the letters. Then continue the print. 
Do these steps for all three files. I would not recommend printing all of the files at once in case you make a mistake and have to start over.

Repeat the same steps for "Percent Infill Label.stl" that goes on the front of the display stand.

Print the "Infill Display Stand.stl" file in the color filament of your choosing. The settings I used were 0.3mm layer height, 2 shells and 5% infill.

Finally glue everything together.

The glue I used is "Model & Hobby Cement" from the dollar store. It's strong but not so strong that you cannot get it apart if you make a mistake.

Enjoy! Teach and spread the knowledge of 3D printing!
.

EDIT: It has been brought to my attention that there is a setting called "top layer height" in the advanced settings of MakerWare and Cura. Setting this to 0 will print the block without the top automatically, so you won't need to cancel the print manually to leave it open so you can see the infill.

comments.text: Very nice display. Though the one thing that it seems everyone forgets is that the % of infill size will changed based on the size of the object, because it is a % of that objects volume. So a 10% infill might give you a 1/4" honeycomb with this example.But if you scale it by 200% it will then give you a 1/2" honeycomb with the same 10% infill.

description.text: Purchased a Flysky FS-T6 transmitter and needed to have the throttle self centering for my application. This arm makes it so channel 3 or the throttle will self center up and down on the controller. You will need a small pull spring to finish the installation. I drilled the post hole out to .067" a #51 drill bit. Works great.

comments.text: Appreciate the comment! I needed it for my Dozer blade up and down. I couldn't keep the blade in the right position. This solved the problem. Found a spring in a home depot spring assortment, great idea with the rubber band. Anyway I am very grateful for the gifts and talents to be able to make things like this. I am very happy to share and so glad you were able to use it also. Thanks!
comments.author: fastmike75

description.text:
Node.js Logo

Node.js is an open source, cross-platform runtime environment for server-side and networking applications. Node.js applications are written in JavaScript and can be run within the Node.js runtime on OS X, Microsoft Windows, Linux, FreeBSD, NonStop, IBM AIX, IBM System z and IBM i. Its work is hosted and supported by the Node.js Foundation, a Collaborative Project at Linux Foundation.

Node.js provides an event-driven architecture and a non-blocking I/O API that optimizes an application's throughput and scalability. These technologies are commonly used for real-time web applications.

Node.js uses the Google V8 JavaScript engine to execute code, and a large percentage of the basic modules are written in JavaScript. Node.js contains a built-in library to allow applications to act as a Web server without software such as Apache HTTP Server or IIS.

This is an attempt to make an all in one HHO system

This is an attempt to make an all in one HHO system
Im thinking that if enough amps ran through this system it should make enough HHO to extend your car or truck's gas mileage.

This model is printed Right side up and all that is needed is some proper sized screws and a rubber gasket or if you have Ninja Flex Filament you can print a gasket, The big hole on the side is for a barb fitting to be threaded in to it with a tap n die set and the small hole on the other side is for a wire to be fed in to it with some conductive material attached to the wire stuff the material and gently pull the wire back through the hole and seal the hole with some kind of silicone, Run DC power to the wires Positive side puts off Oxygen Negative side puts off Hydrogen gas comes out the top of the tanks and in to the bubbler liquid that comes up with the gas if any goes in to the bubbler and the liquid is pulled down to the bottom of the bubbler where its returned to the system via a barbed Tee tube fitting aka a 3 way barb fitting between the tanks you will need to print 2 of these tanks, Tee barb the tubed fittings coming from the bigger holes on the side tube from bottom of bubbler to the Tee fitting between tanks to bring the liquid back to the system that follows the gases to the bubbler. I printed this out to see how it would come out and it came out awesomely in PLA on my XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 extruder temp of 225C and bed temp of 45C and I found at one of my local dollar stores a glue for the bed if u use it its called MOD PODGE its a liquid glue that I apply with a foam brush and it covers the bed great and creates a type of lamination on the bed that the PLA sticks to wonderfully try it out its only a dollar and I use a razor blade paint scraper to get paint off glass to remove the glue and it comes off pretty EZ and comes out of the foam brush with hot water from the tap.

I found some people making HHO on youtube for their cars and I thought how awesome would it be to not have to piece together a system to do that, rather just 3d print the whole thing and then tap the printed holes and screw in a few barb tube fittings and run the proper plumbing and amps of DC current through the system and U get hydrogen & Oxygen which you can pipe in to your air intake and if you can make enough HHO from this system U can extend your fuel mileage a great deal. Videos on youtube just search HHO

This system goes with the bubbler tank listed on thingiverse as
H2O Gassing System Bubbler V2.3

title: Generator / motor disc/rotor to experiment with

description.text:
You have 10 holes for magnets, you could put 1 or 2 or all 10 in there. They could be up to 1 cm diam, and from 1mm to 4mm thick . (If you have less than 1cm diam, you will lose the interferance fit and will need aid of adhesive.) If you have thicker magnets, you could drill the holes deeper probably a few more mm at most, you could maybe drill 1mm increase in diameter, 2 if you like to walk on the wild side ...

This disc-rotor is 1cm thick so I recommend no more than 50% infill, (unless u have alot of extra time, filament is cheap and your printer is ultra fast) ..

I posted the pics of the inside of a 200w rated DC scooter motor for 24v, - you see 4 ceramic magnets, 4 brushes and probably 18 commutator sections - this 3d printed motor disc might make 1/100 of that power maybe 1/20 -- the rotor disc had the intention of a field coil on the perimeter for the 'kick' for rotation, - and one could precisely time a 'pulse' with the use of hall effect sensor to further increase efficiency so that the coil was not on consuming power for the whole time, -- of course if you have all 10 magnets, it just about might need to be on close to full-time .. Then there is (for contrast) a toy DC motor, all DC motors can also be generators when the axis is turned. I put 6.3v to the tiny 13gram motor (I think it was rated for 3v) and it sounded like it was going to self destruct and got hot fairly quickly - but at that voltage it was showing 7-8 watts - i'm sure several thousand rpm. You can see the commutator has 3 seperations, making it a 3 phase motor - 2 magnets and 2 brushes. The power meter showed the voltage , amps and watts (power).

The version 3 disk now has recessed holes for 10mm magnets (that , my recent batch 10x3 measured to diameter of .388 " ) - have a nice tight interference fit (no glue needed)

You will need a coil of wire (or more) in which you will either charge with power to make a motor, or you will receive charge from the spinning magnet (generator). Your coil of course will need to be mounted to some external fixture, such as a chemistry stand and clamp or other improvised holding device.

Of course you will need a shaft for an axis, the given axis hole is 4mm diameter so -- Your shaft will be slightly larger if you want it to spin with the disc. Aluminum or wood dowels would make a nice shaft but then you have the issue of the bearing - I am going to come up with an additional part that allows this disc to be used in conjunction with common household/office products that nearly everyone in the world has access to. The reason we want to drill out this pilot hole is because the drill will make a much smoother (and more accurate) hole than can be printed.
You could use threaded rod with 2 nuts, - sandwhich the disc-rotor in between the 2 nuts for an assembly.
Here is 1 source for magnets: http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D62-N52 .
You could use bearings into the hole of the disc, you may need to drill the hole out for example to fit generic skate bearings in there. This would then be an independent spinning rotor with a stationar shaft. The shaft carries little mechanical motion (if it is not a direct connection to the rotor). You would probaly be using the rotor as a motor in that instance. I am not a motor man, but I play one on (the internet) ... :)

The pic of the coins on the plastic disc is the general concept, of course the coins will be magnets, the disc will be bigger and have near perferct holes for the magnets.

AXIS: if you don't want to use the substitute I suggested, you can print an axis , file : gennyaxis

BASE: this could serve as top and bottom, though a wider / side support base is desireable.

BASE BOTTOM: inherent.

description.text:
10 degree 1306 motor mounts for the Armattan Morphite

Use 2 for each motor mount, its a little bit of a puzzle but you will figure it out.

You will need to enlarge the screw holes a tad depending on how accurate your printer can produce holes. I used a pin vise and reamer.

You will need to enlarge the holes on your morphite frame to allow the bolts to be at a 10 degree angle. I used a needle file.

These came out at 9.3mm on my printer. I used m2x12mm socket head bolts and washers. Be careful not to damage your motors by using bolts that extend into the motor too much.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ef6fFGcviar

I made these belt guides to keep them from slipping off of the Printrbot's 624 bearings. Especially helpful if you're using longer belts (like for the XL bed), or if your bearings aren't exactly aligned.

Both print very quickly, but I'm only using the X belt guide right now (the other one is for Y, even though it isn't labeled as such). They should both work, however.

I forgot to take pictures during installation, but it should be pretty straightforward! Refer to the Instructions tab.

I printed mine at 0.1 mm layer height. Seems to work fine at 15% infill, but you can print it denser if you'd like. They are only 1 mm thick, so it shouldn't take long at all.

On the Simple 1405, the 624 bearings should have been mounted with a single washer against the head of the M4 screw and two washers against the frame. The belt guides will be used in place of the single washer, sitting between the M4 screw head and the 624 bearing.

It is a little tedious to disassemble the printer to install these, but in my opinion very worth the trouble.

This is a threaded adapter for the Dremel to sharped knifes and/or lawn mower blades. There are two different angles for sharpening. I printed it in ABS and used acetone to smooth the threads in order to make it easier to put on.

Update: I printed this on its side without any supports or a raft. I used ABS, and I would advise if you do as well then you should scale it by at least 1%(varies with different printers) to compensate for shrinkage. The threads will be fairly tight, so if that is a concern then scale it just a little more (maybe 1.5%-2%).

Semper Fi

Lulzbot Mini is my first printer I really owned and I love it so much! And it came with a bunch of awesome tools which I always throw around in my room. Thus, here's the tool holder for your Lulzbot Mini!

The tool holder is capable of carry all the tools came with Mini. my extra calipers, craft knife and even more. BTW, the width of tool holder will fit at the front of printer without taking out handle.

Enjoy it and please please let me know your feedback which I could make it even better!

1). The holder will fit the Lulzbot Mini printer bed perfectly. Don's need support.
2). I printed it in PLA with 1mm shell all around with 20% infill.
3). It will use 28.69 gram filament in 20% infill.

description.text: fixed the missing layers in the middle of the part

I just ordered a 12' tall lighting stand for stage/DJ lights. one of the pipe clamps was smashed to pieces when it arrived, and so I thought "this is a job for a 3d printer!!" version 2 update: So I printed out a copy of my original design, and discovered that after a 3 hour print, my pipe dimensions are actually: 1.625" for the bottom tube, then 1.5" inside that tube. This is really important because my original design just had 1.5" for both sections. Whoops. version 3 update: Version 2 snapped after oh-so-moderate tightening. :-\ so I've changed strategies a bit so that I can print this thing in a different orientation. I also moved one of the ends of the clamp to the outer edge so that there's a nice flat side for your thumbscrew or knob or whatever. There's really no reason to have to do all the work in the middle. I've added single-filament-wide walls in a couple of places to support the extreme overhang areas. Snap those off after the print is done. So, here we go again. This is so much faster than ordering a replacement part? It's cheaper than a mechanical engineering degree, certainly. version 4 : removed supports. It didn't work. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/7xWR1K1K2yi
You'll need a couple of 1/4" hex bolts and wing nuts or thumb screws to tighten the sections onto the pipes.

Drawn in 5 minutes for a user is still to be tested...

remixed_from.author: MarcusWolschon
remixed_from.title: Toolhead adapter for RepMan tools in Thing-O-Matic

title: (moved) PCB routing build platform for Thing-O-Matic

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/pcb-routing-build-platform-for-thing-o-matic/ Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html This is an alternative build-platform for the Thing-o-Matic.
(May also fit the Cupcake, You'll have to try.) Using the ABP-quick-release ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8878 )
you can quickly switch your automated build platform for this platform and using
the Repman toolhead adapter ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8738 )
and Dremel Milling Toolhead ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1703 )
you can start milling PCBs. Make mechanics, enclosures AND electronics on your desktop factory! I'm currently preparing a video explaining all the steps
from printing the parts down to setting up VIsolate
for optimized voronoi milling and then actually
milling a spare Thing-o-Matic end-stop. This is already version 1.2 of the platform while I used version 1.1 .
The difference is that you can level the platform using 4 small bolts now. Blog Entry: http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/06/achievement-unlocked-pcb-milling.html Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z14gkPYD0aI

ComponentTraces.pho is a nice file to test this.
It is the upper side of the v1.2 mechanical end-stop for a Thing-o-Matic.
(You can have 3 additional end-stops + 1 emergency-stop -switch.) In the video I describe the basics of running vIsolate
( http://sourceforge.net/projects/visolate/ )
to do optimized voronoi milling of that PCB.
There are lots of other programs to do the g-code generation too.

there are slots on the sides for the clip that i have not tried yet.

you can also use cardboard for the top if you dont want to print out the top part.
that was the plan from the start but i had some time to kill so thought while i was i would print something.

title: WANHAO I3 Adjustable Z endstop REMIX

description.text:
Made the endstop adjustment easier to use and not require any extra M2 hardware. I used M3 grub screws but you could use regular M3 screws as well. You can slide the switch holder up and down and tighten in a desired position, I abandoned the frames M2 mounting.

STL's are upside down feel free to rotate them before printing :D

title: Ultra-Slim Wristband - Clever link system. MakerBot logo or plain versions.

description.text:
This wristband is a very cool wearable 3D item that amazes most people not familiar with 3D printing The strap is only 0.7mm thick and the linking pins (i.e.total height including strap) just 2.9mm tall. This makes it slim, flexible (so comfortable and conforms to your wrist) and is removable as/when you want.

The link takes a bit of practice to link/unlink easily but it's not hard. Once snapped in place it will stay secure until you want to remove it. The side slots weaken the strap where necessary so it shapes to your wrist... and look sporty.

Two versions of .stl's are provided. One with the MakerBot text and the other plain. There are three sizes in each version to suit wrist sizes. If you still need bigger or smaller scale uniformly as required.

If you want to change the colour of the lettering on the MakerBot version pause at 1.0mm (approx. 85% of build) and swap the filament.

Refer to instructions for print details.

Note: If you like this check out all my other designs.

This needs to be printed 'solid' so use 3 shells and 75% infill. Use Std. 0.20mm resolution. Raft not required.

With the MakerBot logo version (MB .stl files) change filamemt colour at 1.0mm or approx. 85% of the build.

comments.text: The wrist band works fine with PLA even though it's more brittle than ABS etc. This is why the sides (curves around your wrist) have slotted sections to make them 'weak areas' so they bend easily to conform to your wrist shape. The PLA prints I've done form to your wrist quickly so become comfortable to wear... PLA is easy!
comments.author: muzz64
